person.persName: The Blessed Virgin of Christ, Susan

birth.note:
Susan was born in Arzun in
Persia

event.desc: At the age of eight, Susan decided to go on pilgrimage to all of the holy sites, but her parents denied her permission.
Susan put her soul into the Lord's hands and fled from her parents.
After three or four miles, she came upon a large party of women and men travelling to Jerusalem and joined them.

personGrp.persName:
A large party of women and men travelling to
Jerusalem

event.desc: After worshipping in Jerusalem, the men and women in Susan's party tried unsuccessfully to bring Susan back with them.
Susan sought out the women's monastery between Ascalon and Gaza.
Susan was at first refused admission to the monastery due to her age, but after three days of waiting outside the gate and weeping, she was admitted.

residence.note:
Women's monastery between
Ascalon and
Gaza

person.persName:
The portress of
the women's monastery between Ascalon and Gaza

event.desc: Susan's companions in the monastery were skeptical of her devotion and tested her.
Susan dedicated herself to fasting, praying, and keeping vigil, which after two years, made her the most devout person in the monastery.
This woman changed her name to Susan so that she would remain hidden from her relatives who were searching for her.

personGrp.persName: The women of the monastery between Ascalon and Gaza

event.desc: After ten years of service in the monastery, the Chalcedonian persecution forced the nuns to conform or go into exile.
The majority of the nuns in Susan's convent conformed, but some chose exile.
Susan chose to go into exile into the desert beyond Alexandria

residence.note: Susan went into the desert beyond Alexandria to live in exile.

event.desc: Of the women who had submitted to the judgments of the Council of Chalcedon, five rejected it and followed Susan into exile.

personGrp.persName: The women of the monastery who submitted the judgments of the Council of Chalcedon
The five women who rejected the Council of Chalcedon and followed Susan

event.desc: Susan heard of a place beyond the House of Mars Menas and directed her steps there.

personGrp.persName: The blessed Syrians, who also went into exile during the persecution and who eventually made Mars Menas their home at a later time.

event.desc: A tower was erected in Mars Menas for protection, in which the women who followed Susan dwelt and made a living from the labor of their hands.
There was a cave outside the tower in the desert near Mendis, where a man once dwelt and to which Susan travelled.

person.persName:
A certain blessed man who lived in a
cave near the village of Mendis

residence.note: The hermit dwelled in the cave near Mendis

event.desc: Susan found the cave in the desert near Mendis and went into it without telling anyone. She went without food or water.
The women who followed Susan into exile became very distressed over her absence because they did not know that she had taken up residence in the hermit's cave.
After ten days, the people of the village were moved by the sisters' weeping and distress and discovered that Susan had been living in the hermit's cave.

personGrp.persName:
Some persons from the village in Mendis who searched for
Susan

event.desc: Susan, who was attacked by demons in the cave day and night, thought that the villagers who discovered her were fiends as well. She did not respond to them when they called out to her.

The villagers went to fetch the sisters, who immediately came to the cave to retrieve Susan. Susan did not respond to their entreaties, since demons had visited her the day before disguised as the sisters in an attempt to dislodge her from the hermitage.

Even though the sisters managed to convince Susan that they were not demons, Susan refused to return to the monastery with them as she wished to live as a hermit. They agreed to bring her a jug of water and seven bread cakes a week for her sustenance on the condition that she not leave without giving them prior notice. This went on for three years, during which time the fame of the Susan and her sisters grew.
People came to Susan and her sisters from Alexandria and from Libya.

personGrp.persName:
Pilgrims who visited Susan and her sisters from
Alexandria and
Libya

event.desc: A great old man and his ten disciples had been Susan's neighbors in a monastery in Palestine before they were driven out of their monastery by the Chalcedonian persecution. They made their way to Susan and her sisters.

person.persName:
A great old man who lived in a monastery near Susan's convent in
Palestine

residence.note: This man resided in a monastery in Palestine.

trait.note:
The ten disciples of the man who resided near Susan in a monastery in
Palestine.

residence.note: These men resided near Susan in a monastery in Palestine before the Chalcedonian persecution.

sex.note: The sister of Samuel was female.

occupation.note: The sister of Samuel was a nun.

birth.note: The sister of Samuel was born in Edessa.

event.desc: Maro and his disciples settled near Susan and her sisters. Many others followed and settled near the holy sisters. The sisters and Susan did not wish to cause scandal by living in such close proximity to men, so they endeavored to leave their tower and go further into the desert.

Maro and his men felt ashamed once they learned of Susan's plan to remove herself and her sisters to the desert and offered to build them an enclosed monastery with a tower within the village, so that they could be isolated but remain close to the other holy men and women who travelled to be near her. Susan reluctantly agreed.

God granted Susan power over the fiends that attacked her day and night in the form of human beings. She continued in this way for fifteen years as her fame grew and people came from far and wide to visit with her and hear her speak. She never showed her face when she spoke in public.
Susan was strong as adamant against the demons and showed no fear of them. They complained bitterly about her strenght.

A blessed man who lived in the desert was regularly assailed by demons and was not as successful as Susan in fighting them. He sought her help and advice. She told him that her power over demons comes from Christ and not from her. She stated that he should not fear the demons if he opposes them in the name of the all-powerful Lord. The man felt ashamed, but was strengthened against the demons.
The blessed man asked Susan why she hasn't shown her face to a man in twenty-five years and she said that it cause her and the person who beheld her face suffering.

person.persName:
The blessed man who struggled against fiends and sought council from
Susan
